;;一张砖房外的黑白“已售出”标志的照片，前面有一棵绿叶树
;

;周二，美国陪审团裁定全国房地产经纪人协会 (NAR) 和一些住宅经纪公司（包括沃伦·巴菲特旗下伯克希尔·哈撒韦公司的子公司）因合谋人为抬高佣金而需支付 17.8 亿美元的赔偿金密苏里州堪萨斯城联邦陪审团的裁决可能会颠覆几十年来的做法，这些做法允许房地产经纪人随着房价和抵押贷款利率的上涨而提高佣金，从而伤害消费者住房交易成本更高。

;

;集体诉讼的原告包括 2015 年至 2022 年间密苏里州、堪萨斯州和伊利诺伊州 260,000 多套房屋的卖家，他们反对有义务向买家经纪人支付佣金。< /p>;

;

;;相关：;;美国银行业危机：沃伦·巴菲特表示老板应该面临“惩罚”;

;
;

;经过两周的审判后，判决结果如下：根据美国反垄断法，损害赔偿金可增加两倍，达到 53 亿美元以上。

;

;“今天是问责日，”原告首席律师迈克尔·凯奇马克 (Michael Ketchmark) 表示。

;

;被告包括伯克希尔旗下的 HomeServices of America 和两家子公司，以及房地产特许经营商 Keller Williams。

;

;NAR 发言人 Mantill Williams 表示，该贸易组织计划上诉，并寻求减少损失。

;

;NAR 发言人 Mantill Williams 表示，该贸易组织计划上诉，并寻求减少损失。 >;

;HomeServices 表示对判决感到失望并计划上诉，而 Keller Williams 发言人 Darryl Frost 表示该房地产公司将考虑上诉的选择。 “这还没有结束，”Frost 说。

;

;美国的经纪人报酬通常约为房屋售价的 5% 至 6%，其中约一半支付给买方经纪人。

;

; >;

;房屋卖家抱怨说，这种模式将买家经纪人的佣金保持在 2.5% 至 3% 的范围内，从而抑制了竞争，尽管经纪人的作用正在减弱，而且许多买家能够在网上独立找到房屋。

;

;卖方表示，这一安排具有“严重的反竞争影响”，并且“除了买方经纪人之外，没有任何经济意义”。

;

;被告否认有不当行为，全国房地产经纪人协会表示，没有证据表明代理人被要求“根本不提供赔偿，更不用说稳定、固定或提高佣金的金额了。”

;

;Re/Max 和 Anywhere Real Estate（其品牌包括 Century 21、Coldwell Banker 和 Corcoran）曾是被告，但已和解审判前，Re/Max 支付了 5500 万美元，Anywhere 支付了 8350 万美元，但不承认责任。

;

;未参与判决的房地产经纪公司股价收低。

;

;Re/Max下跌 4.4%，Anywhere 下跌 2.7%，而在线经纪商 Zillow Group 和 Redfin 分别下跌 6.9% 和 5.7%。

;

;美国司法部分别要求华盛顿联邦上诉法院让其复活对 NAR 的做法进行反垄断调查。

; Wed, 01 Nov 2023 08:52:02 +0800 Nick Clegg compares AI clamour to ‘moral panic’ in 80s over video gameshttps://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/nov/01/nick-clegg-ai-clamour-similar-moral-panic-video-games
;;2023-11-01T00:01:25Z;
;
;;尼克·克莱格于 2022 年在布鲁塞尔 Meta 展厅举行的新闻发布会上发表讲话。
;

;尼克克莱格将对人工智能的喧嚣比作 80 年代对电子游戏的“道德恐慌”，在国际政治家和监管机构聚集参加为期两天的人工智能安全峰会时向他们发出警告。

;

;英国前副首相、现任马克·扎克伯格 Meta 全球事务总裁表示，人工智能陷入了“巨大的炒作周期”，但警告说，新技术会激发过度热情和过度悲观情绪。

;

;英国官员希望使用;Google DeepMind 负责人表示，必须像对待气候危机一样认真对待人工智能风险;

; ;

;“新技术总是会导致炒作，”他说。 “它们常常导致倡导者的过度热情和批评者的过度悲观。

;

;“我记得 80 年代。人们对电子游戏产生了道德恐慌。人们对广播、自行车和互联网产生了道德恐慌。”

;

;在谈到一种强大的人工智能形式可能在几年内出现并带来革命性后果的预测时，他补充道：“这些关于将要发生的事情的预测接下来，即将发生的事情往往并不像那些最深陷其中的人所认为的那样。”

;

;克莱格是本周参加峰会的最有权势的高管之一。其他人包括埃隆·马斯克 (Elon Musk)，他将使用他的 X 社交媒体平台;与英国 Rishi Sunak 就人工智能监管问题进行对话;周四晚上，欧盟委员会主席乌尔苏拉·冯德莱恩 (Ursula von der Leyen) 将是出席会议的最引人注目的国际政治家之一。其他人，包括美国总统乔·拜登和法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙，都决定退出。

;

;一些人认为峰会应该关注短期风险，例如有偏见的决策和使用人工智能进行选举虚假信息的潜力。克莱格表示，他希望代表们讨论如何以“协作方式”为人工智能制作的内容添加水印。

;

;但本周的大部分讨论将集中在长期风险上，包括人工智能将军的潜力智能系统逃避人类控制，许多专家警告说，足够先进的系统甚至可能对人类本身构成威胁。

;

;加州大学伯克利分校计算机科学教授斯图尔特·拉塞尔 (Stuart Russell) 正在参加会议峰会上，周二警告说，目前构建人工智能系统的方法是不安全的。

;

;“我们需要停止考虑让人工智能安全，而开始考虑制造安全的人工智能，”他说。 “我们构建了人工智能，然后我们有一个安全团队来阻止它的不良行为——但这没有奏效，也永远不会奏效。”人工智能安全研究首席执行官康纳·莱希 (Connor Leahy)也将出席峰会的 Conjecture 公司呼吁停止允许私营人工智能公司制造“致命机器”，他称这些机器将控制未来。

;

;他说：“有没有什么比人们了解真相更重要的了：一小群未经选举、下落不明的私营公司正在未经您同意或不知情的情况下对您和您的家人进行致命实验。”

;

;米歇尔·多尼兰 (Michelle Donelan)，英国技术部长在会议前表示：“前沿人工智能带来的风险是严重且实质性的，我们跨部门和国家共同努力认识到这些风险至关重要。”

;

;“本次峰会为我们提供了一个机会，确保我们拥有拥有适当专业知识的合适人员，聚集在一起讨论如何减轻未来的这些风险。只有这样，我们才能以负责任的方式真正获得这项变革性技术的好处。”

;

;英国政府也热衷于强调人工智能的积极潜在用途。峰会期间，部长们将承诺斥资 3800 万英镑，帮助资助世界较贫困地区的“安全且负责任”的人工智能项目，首先是非洲。

;

;官员们表示，峰会的主要目标之一是说服那些处于开发人工智能技术最前沿的人放慢构建最复杂模型的努力。

;

;但是，克莱格的评论表明这可能是一个艰巨的挑战。

;

;“尽管如此，我仍然是一个足够老式的自由主义者，担心国家的死手，”他说。

;

;“在这个领域，允许创新者、建设者——那些他们最终以创业方式开发这些技术的方式非常巧妙，这样做时不会立即假设他们下一步做什么都会带来一些生存风险。”

; Wed, 01 Nov 2023 08:52:02 +0800 Hong Kong: over-the-top punishment for 2019 democracy protesters, report findshttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/01/hong-kong-over-the-top-punishment-for-2019-democracy-protesters-report-finds
;;2023-11-01T00:25:26Z;
;
;;2019 年 8 月 2 日，人们参加香港中环公务员举行的抗议活动，反对计划中的引渡法迅速演变成一场更广泛的民主改革运动
;

;参与2019-2020年民主运动的抗议者;与本地和国际标准相比，香港;受到刑事司法系统的异常严厉对待，;报告;有发现。

;

;;大规模抗议十年：为什么2010年代的街头运动失败了？;

; ;

;截至2022年8月，已有超过10,000名香港人因与抗议活动有关而被捕据政府统计，2019 年抗议运动中有近 3,000 人被起诉。乔治城大学的研究人员分析了截至 2021 年 7 月 31 日结案的 1,500 多个案件。

;

;抗议者被指控犯有 100 种不同类型的罪行。其中包括非法集会、骚乱、警察阻碍和袭击警察。超过 80% 的被定罪者被判处监禁，而因雨伞运动相关指控被定罪的人只有 31% 多一点。数据集中最常见的指控是非法集会，这是一项殖民时代的法令，允许当局起诉和平抗议者。

;

;2019 年至 2020 年，反送中法案抗议活动持续了 6 个多月，比 2014 年的雨伞运动还要长。他们最终在 2020 年 6 月被严厉的;国家安全法（NSL）;，有效禁止一切形式的异议，最高可判处无期徒刑。中国和香港当局表示，需要通过该法律来恢复稳定。

;

;截至 9 月，已有 280 人因《国家安全法》被捕，其中包括活动人士黄之锋和前媒体老板等知名人士;黎智英;。这些案件在不同的法院审理，法官由行政部门亲自挑选。

;

;但抗议活动后，大多数人都被指控犯有更普通的罪行，其中许多人因其他原因被拘留。审前拘留数月。

;

;2019年至2021年，刑事审判的平均等待时间增加了50%，达到287天，远远超出了100天的官方目标。报告称：“如此漫长的等待时间表明，法院系统在案件数量大幅增加的重压下陷入困境。”

;

;研究人员分析的案件中，超过 130 名被告年龄在 18 岁以下，中位年龄为 23 岁。超过 66% 的青少年定罪导致监禁，研究人员将其描述为“儿童入狱率极高”。

;

;相比之下，在英格兰和威尔士， 2021 年，被定罪的青少年中有 5% 被拘留。

;

;香港公开表达异议的情况;现在极其罕见;。 3 月份，在警方的密切监视下，发生了一场针对填海计划的小规模抗议活动，这是自 2020 年以来首次允许任何形式的示威活动。

;

;该市行政长官李约翰 (John Lee) 表示，除北京于 2020 年实施的国家安全法外，引入另一项香港国家安全法是 2024 年的优先事项。

; Wed, 01 Nov 2023 08:52:02 +0800 Biden expected to meet with Xi Jinping next month for ‘constructive’ talkshttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/oct/31/biden-xi-jinping-meeting-us-china
;;2023-10-31T22:00:32Z;
;
;;美国总统乔·拜登和中国国家主席习近平于 2022 年 11 月 14 日在巴厘岛会晤。
;

;乔预计拜登将在峰会期间会见中国领导人;习近平;白宫周二表示，将于 11 月在旧金山举行峰会，进行“建设性”会谈。

;

;几天前，中国外交部长罕见地访问华盛顿，为习近平在亚太经合组织（APEC）峰会。

;

;中国尚未确认习近平是否会来。

;
;

;;相关：;;习近平表示，随着与拜登会谈的希望上升，中国愿意与美国合作;

;
;

;“我们的目标是在旧金山举行建设性对话、会晤。” 11 月，”白宫新闻秘书 Karine Jean-Pierre 在谈到期待已久的会谈时说道。

;

;“这就是下个月 11 月将要发生的事情。我们正在旧金山进行建设性对话。我想我刚刚确认了这一点，”她补充道。

;

;一位美国政府高级官员告诉法新社：“原则上已达成协议，将于 11 月在旧金山举行会议。我们仍在研究最终敲定这些计划所需的重要细节。”

;

;自;2022 年 11 月在巴厘岛举行会议;。

;

;多年来两国关系一直紧张世界最大的两个经济体之间正在争夺在亚太地区及其他地区的影响力，同时北京加强与俄罗斯的合作以削弱美国的主导地位。

;

;在北京最高外交官王毅会见高级官员之后美国官员上周在白宫表示，双方“正在共同努力进行会晤”。

;

;但中国外交部长周六表示，谈判之路仍然“并不顺利”。< /p>;

;王毅在阿斯彭战略集团主办的华盛顿活动中表示，“双方希望尽快稳定和改善双边关系，并同意共同努力推动两国元首在旧金山举行峰会”，据官方通讯社新华社报道。

;

;据新华社报道，王警告说，“通往旧金山的道路并不平坦，不能任其‘自动驾驶’。”

;

;双方必须“排除干扰、克服障碍、凝聚共识、积累成果”。

; Wed, 01 Nov 2023 06:52:01 +0800 Colombian police identify two suspects in abduction of Luis Díaz’s fatherhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/31/colombian-police-identify-two-suspects-in-abduction-of-luiz-diazs-father-liverpool
;;2023-10-31T21:56:11Z;
;
;;威廉·萨拉曼卡将军在搜寻路易斯·曼努埃尔·迪亚斯（利物浦球员路易斯·迪亚斯被绑架的父亲）的行动中指挥士兵。< /div>;

;哥伦比亚警方已确认绑架哥伦比亚足球运动员路易斯·迪亚斯父亲的四名男子中的两名，安全部队正在加紧阻止绑架者将他偷运到邻国委内瑞拉。

;

;路易斯·曼努埃尔·迪亚斯和他的妻子 Cilenis Marulanda 周六在哥伦比亚北部拉瓜希拉州巴兰卡斯的一个加油站被武装人员绑架。尽管马鲁兰达在同一天获释，但对老迪亚兹的搜寻仍在拉瓜希拉进行，这是一个靠近委内瑞拉的沙漠地区，这里是走私违禁品和可卡因的武装团体的温床。

;
;

;;相关：;;路易斯·迪亚斯的磨难使尤尔根·克洛普和利物浦队成为“最艰难的比赛”;

;
;

;国家警察局长威廉·萨拉曼卡将军与士兵们一起参加了周一，他们在与委内瑞拉接壤的佩里哈山脉的云林中进行了挂锁行动，以寻找老迪亚兹下落的线索。至少 200 名哥伦比亚安全部队成员已出动，其中包括精锐地面部队和正在空中进行搜索的专业飞行员。

;

;警察部队也在哥伦比亚周边地区挨家挨户进行搜查。国家警察局副局长亚历杭德罗·萨帕塔 (Gen Alejandro Zapata) 在波哥大举行的新闻发布会上表示，他们正在寻找任何可能安全救回迪亚兹老先生的信息，并悬赏 48,000 美元（39,000 英镑）。周一，他表示徒步穿越山脉并不容易，但绑匪的合理目标是把他带出该国并远离哥伦比亚当局的控制。 “我们目前没有任何证据表明他已经越境，我们不能肯定这一点，但我们也不能排除这种可能性，”他说。 “他们很可能会寻找逃离那里的可能性。”

;

;哥伦比亚情报部门正在与国际刑警组织驻委内瑞拉首都加拉加斯的办事处合作，但尚未证实迪亚兹老先生已离开该国萨帕塔说。哥伦比亚国家反敲诈勒索部门的发言人证实，没有接到任何电话索取金钱以换取他的自由。

;

;随着国家经济的发展，委内瑞拉在过去十年中已成为武装团体的避难所。一些游击队与军方勾结，从事金矿开采和毒品走私等非法活动。哥伦比亚安全部队经常将有组织犯罪激增归咎于委内瑞拉缺乏法律和秩序，因为黑手党在哥伦比亚实施抢劫或敲诈勒索后很容易越境溜回。

;

;Feli Ureche，Díaz Sr 的堂兄弟之一，;告诉波哥大W 广播电台称，老迪亚兹在被绑架之前曾受到威胁;，他被绑架的震惊在哥伦比亚全国引起了强烈的声援。该国在 90 年代和 2000 年代是世界绑架之都，但近几十年来变得更加安全，该国最大的游击队终于在 2016 年放下了枪，作为具有里程碑意义的和平进程的一部分。

;

; “有比足球比赛更重要的事情。拜托，我们生活在一个什么样的社会里，”路易斯·迪亚斯的哥伦比亚队友詹姆斯·罗德里格斯在社交媒体上发帖说。 “我们和你在一起，卢奇托。”

;

;迪亚兹 ;2022 年 1 月以 4000 万欧元的初始价格从波尔图加盟利物浦;。这名边锋被排除在;在听到他父母的遭遇后，周日在安菲尔德以 3-0 击败诺丁汉森林;。

;

;迪亚兹与其他家人一起留在英格兰的家中。利物浦的助理教练 Pepijn Lijnders 在周二的新闻发布会上拒绝详细说明俱乐部为这位 26 岁的球员提供了哪些支持，但坚称迪亚兹知道他得到了所有人的支持。

;

;“卢乔他总是面带微笑，与每个人都保持着令人难以置信的关系。我们真的很关心他，”林德斯说。 “现在对我们来说唯一的事情就是尽我们所能地支持他。很多事情都是我们无法掌控的——这是完全正常的。我们希望当地当局能够找到他的父亲，一切都好。我们只是为此祈祷。

;

; Wed, 01 Nov 2023 04:52:01 +0800 ‘Nastiness, arrogance and misogyny’ of UK government exposed at Covid inquiryhttps://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/oct/31/covid-inquiry-exposes-incompetence-backstabbing-and-misogyny

;
;;Dominic Cummings arrives to give evidence at the Covid inquiry.
;

;A toxic culture of government incompetence, backstabbing and misogyny was laid bare at the Covid public inquiry on Tuesday with messages revealing Boris Johnson's dismissive attitude to millions of old people at risk from the virus.

;

;The former prime minister's top aide Dominic Cummings was accused of “aggressive, foul-mouthed and misogynistic” abuse after messages showed he tried to sack top civil servant Helen MacNamara saying No 10 was “dodging stilettos from that cunt”.

;

;Johnson's chaotic indecisiveness delayed lockdown measures, the inquiry heard, while he had told senior advisers the Covid virus was “just nature's way of dealing with old people” and he was “no longer buying” the fact the NHS was overwhelmed during the pandemic.

;

;Bereaved relatives reacted to the fresh evidence with horror after a bruising session of the Covid inquiry, with Cummings and Lee Cain, the former No 10 director of communications, questioning Johnson's suitability for leading the country during the pandemic.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Eight shocking revelations from Cummings and Cain at the Covid inquiry;

;
;

;Susie Flintham, spokesperson for Covid-19 Bereaved Families for Justice UK said: “The nastiness, arrogance and misogyny at the heart of government during the pandemic is core to the awful decision making that led to thousands of unnecessary deaths and tore families like mine apart. When you see that these figures had such a shocking disregard for each other, you can only imagine the disregard they had for families like mine.”

;

;In a lengthy session before the inquiry, Cummings claimed the cabinet had been “largely irrelevant” to Covid policy in 2020, and that he was “reflecting a widespread view” that if anything understated the problem, when he used expletive-laden descriptions of ministers including “useless fuckpigs”, “morons” and “cunts”.

;

;Whatsapps and documents seen by the inquiry showed that he had brutally mocked and criticised former cabinet secretary Mark Sedwill and his deputy MacNamara, while casting particular disdain on former health secretary Matt Hancock.

;

;“Hancock is unfit for this job,” he wrote. “无能、不断的谎言、对媒体废话的痴迷。 Still no fucking serious testing in care homes his uselessness is still killing god knows how many.”

;

;In another message in August 2020, Cummings said: “I also must stress I think leaving Hancock in post is a big mistake – he is a proven liar who nobody believes or [should] believe on anything. We face going into autumn crisis with the cunt in charge of NHS still.”

;

;Cummings claimed that Sedwill “hasn't a scooby whats going on”, warning that the Cabinet Office was “terrifyingly shit” in a WhatsApp to Johnson in March 2020, as the pandemic ramped up. The inquiry's lead counsel, Hugo Keith, said he had “denigrated and insulted” the former cabinet secretary.

;

;However, it was his messages about MacNamara that attracted the most criticism from the senior lawyer, after Cummings suggested in them that he would “personally handcuff her and escort her from the building” if he had to spend time responding to her questions about government propriety and ethics.

;

;“I don't care how it's done.但那个女人一定不在我们的范围内。 We cannot keep dealing with this horrific meltdown of the British state while dodging stilettos from that cunt,” he had written.

;

;Cummings apologised for his language towards MacNamara, who appears before the inquiry on Wednesday, saying it was “obviously appalling” but denied that it was mysogynistic because he was “much ruder about men”. He added: “A thousand times worse than my language was the underlying insanity of the situation in No 10.”

;

;In his final WhatsApp to his former closest aide on 15 November 2020, Johnson described the infighting surrounding Cummings' departure from Downing Street two days earlier as a “disgusting orgy of narcissism”.

;

;The government's handling of the pandemic continues to hang over Downing Street even though it is more than a year since Johnson left No 10, with the former prime minister joining Rishi Sunak and other senior figures to give evidence before Christmas.

;

;However, the Guardian revealed last month that Sunak has failed to hand over his own WhatsApp messages from his time as chancellor to the Covid inquiry despite the high court ruling that ministers should disclose their communications for scrutiny.

;

;Cummings told the inquiry how the “dysfunctional system” during a “meltdown of the British state” had failed to deal with the crisis, while Lee Cain, who served as No 10's communications director, criticised Johnson's tendency to “oscillate” between decisions for slowing down the government's response.

;

;In his evidence, Cain said Johnson had the wrong “skill set” to lead the country through the pandemic, leaving his senior aides “exhausted” by constantly changing his mind on crucial decisions. He said that Downing Street decided a full lockdown was needed in March 2020 a full 10 days before it was announced.

;

;The former chief scientific adviser, Sir Patrick Vallance, in ;his diaries; described a “bonkers set of exchanges” in a meeting from August 2020 during which Johnson appeared “obsessed with older people accepting their fate” and letting young people get on with their lives.

;

;Another note from Vallance, after a cabinet meeting in December 2020, hinted at the power wielded by the right of the Conservative party during the pandemic: “PM told he has been acting early and the public are with him (but his party is not).

;

;“He says his party 'thinks the whole thing is pathetic and Covid is just nature's way of dealing with old people – and I am not entirely sure I disagree with them. A lot of moderate people think it is a bit too much.'”

;

;In a WhatsApp message sent to his top aides in October 2020, the former prime minister said he had been “slightly rocked” by Covid infection rates and suggested he was, as a result, unconvinced that hospitals were on the brink despite public warnings from NHS chiefs and frontline staff.

;

;Cummings also told the inquiry that “pretty much everyone” called Johnson “the trolley” due to his constant veering about on the pandemic, while vulnerable people such as the poor and victims of domestic abuse were “almost entirely, appallingly neglected” at the start of the crisis.

;

;However, he had no regrets about putting Johnson in office despite thinking he was unfit to be there, adding: “Politics is about choices … We thought combination of second referendum and Corbyn was so bad [ahead of the 2019 election] that we should roll the dice.”

;

;Cummings was unapologetic about his lockdown-busting trip to Durham in Spring 2020 but admitted regret for Downing Street's “absolute car crash” handling of the row which he said had caused “huge pain” to many people.

;

;Messages released to the inquiry showed that Johnson denied he had ever been told by Cummings about the trip, accusing him of being a “total and utter liar” even though he had “tried my very best to defend him” after the Guardian and Daily Mirror broke the story.

;

;The former top adviser criticised Johnson's focus on the media throughout the pandemic, suggesting it was “extremely bad and extremely damaging” to the government's Covid response.

;

;He flagged particular concerns about his relationship with the Daily Telegraph, which pushed against lockdowns, and said there was “possible corruption” in his relationship with the Evening Standard, edited by former chancellor George Osborne and owned by Tory peer Evgeny Lebedev, a reference to generous advertising spending.

; Wed, 01 Nov 2023 04:22:01 +0800 Seeds of doubt: mystery remains over how sunflowers track lighthttps://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/oct/31/seeds-of-doubt-mystery-remains-over-how-sunflowers-track-light
;;2023-10-31T18:39:17Z;
;
;;Sunflowers in a field.
;

;With their bright yellow manes and sturdy stems, sunflowers might seem like a simple summer delight. But researchers say the plants are surprisingly enigmatic after discovering they don't use conventional processes to track the sun across the sky.

;

;Over the course of a day, sunflowers follow the path of the sun overhead – a process known as heliotropism – with their heads tilting progressively westwards as a result of cells elongating on the east side of the stem. At night, cells elongate on the opposite side of the stems resulting in the heads reorienting themselves towards the east.

;

;However researchers say that the processes behind the solar tracking are an unexpected mystery.

;

;“So many of our results were different than we anticipated,” said Prof Stacey Harmer, an author of the research at University of California, Davis.

;

;Many plants grow towards a light source – this is because when blue light receptors, called phototropins, are activated on the lighted side of the stem, they cause hormones called auxins to become concentrated on the other “dark” side. These auxins stimulate an elongation of cells, resulting in the stem bending towards the light.

;

;While new research suggests this mechanism explains how sunflowers bend towards artificial light indoors, it appears it does not account for the way sunflowers naturally track the path of the sun.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Kansas man plants 1.2m sunflowers as 50th anniversary gift for his wife;

;
;

;Writing in the journal Plos One, Harmer and colleagues reported that they first analysed which genes were switched on within the stems of sunflowers grown indoors, when artificial blue light was shone from one direction.

;

;The results suggest genes relating to phototropins were primarily “switched on” within the lighted side of the stem, with those related to and auxins and cell growth switched on within the shady side, suggesting sunflowers grown indoors turn towards blue light as a result of conventional processes.

;

;But when the team turned to the stems of outdoor sunflowers, they found something different. The east side of the stem, the side in sunlight, and the west side, the side in shade, showed little difference in terms of which of these genes were switched on.

;

;The researchers then tried blocking blue and ultraviolet or red and far-red light on their own, found neither attempt alone affected heliotropism in the outdoor plants, suggesting multiple light-signalling pathways are likely at play at the same time.

;

;In another twist, the team found when sunflowers grown indoors were moved outdoors, the plants began tracking the sun immediately. However, a different pattern of genes was switched on across their stems on their first day outside compared with when they were indoors or on subsequent days outdoors – suggesting some sort of adjustment mechanism was at play.

;

;Harmer said the work suggests findings obtained in controlled environments don't necessarily reflect what is happening in the wild.

;

;“Our results suggest that both solar tracking and phototropism in real world conditions is much more complicated than we had expected,” she said.
